EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
CITY OF PORT ST. JOE
WATER TREATMENT PLANT

POLICY
It is the policy of the City of Port St. Joe's Water Treatment Plant (WTP) to conduct its business to insure the likelihood of a release of chlorine is minimized and if there is a release the offsite consequence will be reduced.  To accomplish this the chlorine ton cylinders, pipe lines, fittings, and injectors are maintained according to good engineering and maintenance practices.  DOT regulations and using only parts, equipment and procedures that conform to Chlorine Institute's specifications.  Our operating and maintenance employees utilizing the chlorine system are trained annually in the requirements of chlorine safety.

Description of Industrial Wastewater Treatment Plant Operation
The City of Port St. Joe operates a 2mgd ground and surface water treatment plant.  The WTP utilizes the following processes, line softening, aeration, stabilization and chlorination after the treatment plant.  Raw water for the treatment plant is obtained from two wells and a fresh water canal.

Description of chlorine system
The chlorine system consists of ton cylinders connected through an injector into the force main feeding the chlorine contact system.  Chlorine feed rate is based on the need to maintain a residual chlorine concentration through out the potable water distribution system.  Chlorine is withdrawn from the cylinder by vacuum through Wallace & Tiernan V-75 Chlorinator and no external vaporizer is used in the process.

RMP requirements at the facility
A review of all the materials used at the WTP has determined that chlorine is the only substance at or above a threshold quantity of an RMP regulated substance.  The quantity of chlorine is enough to have a worst-case release scenario offsite impact thus a Program 2 level RMP has been developed.

Worst-case release scenario
The maximum quantity of chlorine that will be in the largest container on site at any one time will be 2,000 pounds.  This is a s

ingle one ton cylinder.  The maximum quantity of chlorine that will be released in a worst-case scenario is 2,000 pounds at a release rate of 200 pounds per minute.  A worst-case release of any one cylinder will not cause an effect on the other cylinders.  This will result in a distance to the endpoint is 3.0 miles using the Model Aloha 5.2.1

Administrative controls
There is no administrative controls on chlorine inventory in use at the facility that will effect the worst-case release scenario.

Passive controls
There are no passive control measures in place at the facility.

Alternative release scenario
A cylinder is in service with a regulator in place.  The regulator is hit causing the regulator to break off.  This will result in a leak equal to the maximum withdrawal rate from the cylinder.  Release quantity of chlorine will be 23.4 pounds or 0.39 pounds/ minute and last for 60 minutes.  The distance to the endpoint using the Model ALOHA 5.2.1 is 125 yards.  Under all conditions of alternative release scenarios there will be one house within the circle, this is occupied by the WTP operator.

Five-year accidental release history
There have been no RMP releases of chlorine within the five years of 1994 to date.

Accidental release prevention program
An OSHA PSM program is not required for this facility for chlorine.  Our operators are trained in chlorine safety and correct operating procedures.  The operators conduct inspection rounds of the WWTP, including the chlorine system, to insure the WWTP is operating correctly.  Any concerns, including safety of the chlorine process, are reported to the maintenance department so corrections can be made.  Our maintenance employees are trained in chlorine safety and how to complete the required work.

General prevention activities
The facility has a staff of experienced and knowledgable employees that receive refresher safety training annually.  Each employee working with chlorine has the training and experience needed to

approach a leak, determine its cause and take corrective actions.  Any event involving a release of chlorine is investigated and a root cause determined.

Emergency response program
This facility's employees will respond to an emergency release scenario of chlorine which could have an offsite consequence.  The Gulf County Emergency Management Agency and the City of Port St. Joe Fire department has been informed of the storage of chlorine and have a copy of this Risk Management Plan.

The Gulf County Emergency Management Agency and the City of Port St. Joe Fire Department was given the opportunity to inspect the site and make recommendations for inclusion in this Risk Management Program development.  Their recommendation are included in the documentation.
